A: The problem is not with the emojis, but with the encoding. You are using UTF-8 encoding to send the data. UTF-8 can handle almost all characters, but for some characters it uses more than one byte. If the server or database does not support UTF-8, it may not be able to correctly interpret these characters.

In your case, you are using the DataOutputStream.write method, which writes the bytes directly to the output stream. This method does not handle character encoding. It is your responsibility to ensure that the characters you write are encoded correctly.

To solve this, you should use the OutputStreamWriter, which is a writer that uses a specific charset for encoding characters. You can specify the charset as UTF-8. Here is how you can modify your code:

```java
private void buildTextPart(DataOutputStream dataOutputStream, String parameterName, String parameterValue) throws IOException {
    dataOutputStream.writeBytes(twoHyphens + boundary + lineEnd);
    dataOutputStream.writeBytes("Content-Disposition: form-data; name=" + parameterName + lineEnd);
    dataOutputStream.writeBytes("Content-Type: text/plain; charset=UTF-8" + lineEnd);
    dataOutputStream.writeBytes(lineEnd);

    OutputStreamWriter writer = new OutputStreamWriter(dataOutputStream, "UTF-8");
    writer.write(parameterValue);
    writer.flush();
}
```

This code will ensure that the parameterValue is encoded correctly in UTF-8 and sent to the server.

Also, ensure that the server or database is configured to use UTF-8 as the character set for handling text data.
